item.title: By: randomactsofmath
item.dc:creator: randomactsofmath
item.description:
Sharad and dreeves,
Thanks! It was indeed the use of the term "bear market", that was confusing. For a risk-neutral investor, the volatility means nothing, but once one factors in the asymmetric treatment of gains and losses, it becomes a lot more clear. I do not know enough about Cumulative Prospect Theory, but it could be interesting to work out what this number says about the expectations of those trading the markets, according to CPT assumptions.
I look forward to more posts.

item.title: By: dreeves
item.dc:creator: dreeves
item.description: R.A. O'Math, I don't think Sharad is claiming such correlation. He's just saying that when people less disingenuous than Jim Cramer are bearish or bullish they can't literally be predicting the direction of the market. So he's giving them the benefit of the doubt that they are predicting volatility instead. If you're risk-averse then a volatile market is more bearish than bullish.

item.title: By: Sharad Goel
item.dc:creator: Sharad Goel
item.content:encoded:
John asks (via email) how monthly volatility is computed from yearly volatility. Here’s the answer. It’s assumed (e.g., in Black-Scholes) that the log stock price process follows a Brownian motion, and that volatility is the standard deviation of this random walk. If Xi is the change in the walk in month i, the change in a year is X = X1 + X2 + … + X12. By independence,

σyearly = √12 σmonthly.

This model assumes constant volatility. Implied volatility, however, has been empirically observed to depend both on an option’s strike price and on its time to maturity, leading to the volatility smile.
